item.title: Wall Street Sees Deeper Dollar Rout as Currency Nears 2023 Low
item.description: Wall Street banks are reinforcing their calls that the dollar will weaken further, hit by interest-rate cuts, slowing economic growth and President Donald Trump’s trade and tax policies.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson, Aline Oyamada

item.title: Leela Luxury Hotels Owner’s India IPO Gets Off to a Tepid Start
item.description: The shares of the operator of the India’s Leela luxury hotels made a lackluster debut in Mumbai after having raised money through India’s second-largest initial public offering this year.
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon, Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Bond Buyers Are Turning Their Backs on the US 30-Year
item.description: Debt, deficit have DoubleLine, TCW shunning long bonds
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie, Phil Serafino

item.title: Treasuries Fall as Tariff Uncertainty Clouds Outlook Before Data
item.description: Treasuries fell amid a broad selloff of US assets as uncertainty over President Donald Trump’s tariff policy continued to swirl at the start of a busy week for data on the health of the world’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: James Hirai

item.title: Hedge Fund Picton Buys Volatility, Fearing a New Tariff Tantrum
item.description: The head of Canada’s Picton Mahoney Asset Management said the global market volatility that has faded in recent weeks is likely to return, and his firm is betting on it.
item.dc:creator: Layan Odeh, Derek Decloet

item.title: Stocks Fall as Trade Risk Flare-Up Saps Confidence: Markets Wrap
item.description: Global stocks started the new month under pressure as an escalation in global trade tensions and geopolitical uncertainty weakened investor confidence.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Allegra Catelli

item.title: Fed’s Waller Outlines Path to ‘Good News’ Rate Cuts This Year
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller continues to see a path to interest-rate cuts later this year and outlined a scenario in which he would be supporting “good news rate cuts later this year.” Waller spoke at a Bank of Korea conference in Seoul on Monday. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New World’s Distress Worsens After Delay on Bond Interest
item.description: Hong Kong developer New World Development Co. is sliding deeper into distress after jolting investors by delaying interest payments on some bonds, marking the latest flashpoint in a years-long crisis in China’s property market.
item.dc:creator: Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu

item.title: Thiel-Backed Psychedelic Drugmaker Atai to Combine With Beckley
item.description: Atai Life Sciences NV agreed to buy full control of smaller UK rival Beckley Psytech Ltd. and raised $30 million in fresh equity, as it seeks to cement its position as one of the leading makers of psychedelic drugs for mental health conditions.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning

media:content.media:description: Mushrooms that contain psilocybin in a laboratory.

item.title: Bangladesh Narrows Fiscal Deficit, Cuts Spending in Budget
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim government targeted a smaller fiscal deficit and lower spending in its maiden budget, as the South Asian nation aims to meet conditions for future International Monetary Fund loans, critical for the crisis-hit economy.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Street vendors sell vegetables in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: JPMorgan Strategists Warn US Stock Rally at Risk From Stagflation
item.description: Higher prices and weaker US economic growth over the summer are likely to threaten the S&P 500’s rally, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: The JP Morgan Chase & Co. headquarters in New York.

item.title: Buyers’ Strike Rocks US Long Bond as DoubleLine, Pimco Stay Away
item.description: For DoubleLine Capital, there are two approaches to consider when it comes to 30-year US Treasuries: either avoid them, to the degree they can, or outright short them.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie

item.title: Monzo Profit Soars as British Challenger Bank Boosts Lending
item.description: Monzo Bank Ltd. said its profit quadrupled last year with a burgeoning loan book and customer growth lifting revenue, as the mobile bank works toward an eventual stock market debut.
item.dc:creator: Aisha S Gani

media:content.media:description: The Monzo Bank logo on a smartphone.

item.title: Chinese Automaker BYD Faces Backlash Over EV Price War
item.description: BYD Co. shares fell on concern that its price cuts are drawing government scrutiny and becoming unsustainable for the Chinese electric vehicle industry. Bloomberg’s Katrina Nicholas reports.

item.title: India Seeks Bigger, More Frequent Dividends From State-Run Firms
item.description: The Indian government is asking state-run companies to increase dividend payouts by about 25% this financial year as Asia’s third-largest economy seeks to bolster finances in a volatile global environment, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Singh

media:content.media:description: The North Block of the Central Secretariat building in New Delhi. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Analysts’ Bullish Reviews Mask Weak Conviction in US Stock Rally
item.description: After a furious May rally, Wall Street analysts now have more buy ratings on individual companies in the S&P 500 Index than at any time in more than two decades, according to a Jefferies LLC analysis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: UK House Prices Post Surprise Increase in May, Nationwide Says
item.description: UK house prices unexpectedly rose in May, in a sign that demand for housing remains resilient following the expiry of a tax break for buyers, according to one of Britain’s largest mortgage lenders.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Homes in London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Europe Defense Stocks Hit Fresh Record as UK to Ramp Up Spending
item.description: Europe’s high-flying defense stocks got another boost on Monday as the UK unveiled plans to expand its submarine fleet and shore up its nuclear deterrent.
item.dc:creator: Kit Rees

media:content.media:description: A Leopard 2 tank transmission on the production line at a Renk AG plant in Germany.

item.title: Virgin Atlantic CEO Sees 'Momentum' in India
item.description: Virgin Atlantic Chief Executive officer Shai Weiss discusses the impact of trade and tariffs uncertainty on the airline and broader aviation industry. He also talks about fuel prices and travel sentiment. Speaking to Bloomberg's Guy Johnson from the sidelines of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) in New Delhi, India, Weiss says "the momentum is very much" in India at the moment. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Advances as OPEC+ Supply Boost Vies With Geopolitical Risk
item.description: Oil advanced after OPEC+ increased production less than some had feared and geopolitical concerns flared over Ukraine and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: A flame burns off waste gas at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, on Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: Indonesia Trade Surplus Shrinks as Global Tariff Fears Boost Imports from China
item.description: Indonesia posted its smallest trade surplus in more than five years on signs importers are stocking up on goods from China and other key trading partners to mitigate the risks of rising global tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: The Sunda Kelapa Port in Jakarta, Indonesia.

item.title: Gold Surges With Rising Global Tensions Boosting Haven Demand
item.description: Gold surged on revived demand for safer assets as the US and China traded accusations, while a dramatic series of attacks clouded the prospects of peace between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Sybilla Gross

item.title: Air France-KLM CEO Says Premium Demand Is Holding
item.description: Air France-KLM Chief Executive Officer Ben Smith says “premium demand” for the airline “is holding across all of our sectors.” Smith speaks to Bloomberg’s Guy Johnson from the sidelines of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) annual meeting in New Delhi, India. He also discusses the potential impact of tariffs and trade uncertainty on the airline, as well as merger and acquisition prospects.

item.title: South Africa Farm Exports Surge 10% as US Shipments Climb
item.description: South African agricultural exports rose 10% in the first quarter to $3.36 billion from a year earlier as port performance improved and shipments to the US climbed, an industry body said.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Workers box fruit at a citrus farm in South Africa.

item.title: British Factories ‘Turning a Corner’ After US-UK Tariffs Deal
item.description: British factories showed signs of “turning a corner” in May following a limited deal between Keir Starmer and Donald Trump’s governments to lower some US tariffs, a closely watched survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: An employee works on a scanner on the manufacturing production line near Oxford.

item.title: Chinese Shares Fall in Hong Kong on New Trade Frictions With US
item.description: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu

item.title: India Confirms It Lost Fighter Jets in Recent Pakistan Conflict
item.description: General Anil Chauhan, chief of defence staff of the Indian Armed Forces, speaks about the recent India-Pakistan conflict and what happened to Indian jets. He was interviewed at the Shangri-La Dialogue security conference in Singapore by Bloomberg TV's Haslinda Amin. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Markets Are Increasingly Discounting Tariff News: Nuveen
item.description: Laura Cooper, Nuveen global investment strategist and head of macro credit, says this week’s nonfarm payrolls report is key for assessing the impact of President Donald Trump’s trade policies on the US economy. Markets are “increasingly discounting” the tariff news, Cooper tells Bloomberg Television. “We’re more focused on the extent of economic damage that is potentially going to come through in US data,” she adds.

item.title: As Private Equity Returns Dwindle, Executives Look to Soothe Antsy Investors
item.description: As buyout executives gather for their yearly jamboree in Berlin, some are talking about the once dominant industry becoming a niche asset class.
